snippet: A strict anti-spending provision in the state Constitution may force Colorado to refund nearly $60 million intended for school construction and other needs.
abstract: Millions of tax dollars from recreational marijuana sales are flooding Colorado's coffers, but due to anti-spending provision in state's Constitution, it may have to refund nearly $60 million to drug's consumers, growers and the public; lawmakers are hoping Colorado's generally anti-tax public will approve bill allowing state to keep money for school construction and other needs.
lead_paragraph: A strict anti-spending provision in the state Constitution may force Colorado to refund nearly $60 million intended for school construction and other needs.

headline.main: In Colorado, Marijuana Taxes May Have to Be Passed Back
headline.print_headline: In Colorado, Marijuana Taxes May Have to Be Passed Back
